column2: CHAPTER 27
column3: CHAPTER twenty seven

column2: The next morning brought the following very unexpected letter from Isabella:
column3: The next morning brought the following very unexpected letter from Isabella:

column2: Bath, April
column3: Bath, April

column2: My dearest Catherine, I received your two kind letters with the greatest delight, and have a thousand apologies to make for not answering them sooner.
column3: My dearest Catherine, I received your two kind letters with the greatest delight, and have a thousand apologies to make for not answering them sooner.

column2: I really am quite ashamed of my idleness; but in this horrid place one can find time for nothing.
column3: I really am quite ashamed of my idleness; but in this horrid place one can find time for nothing.

column2: I have had my pen in my hand to begin a letter to you almost every day since you left Bath, but have always been prevented by some silly trifler or other.
column3: I have had my pen in my hand to begin a letter to you almost every day since you left Bath, but have always been prevented by some silly trifler or other.

column2: Pray write to me soon, and direct to my own home.
column3: Pray write to me soon, and direct to my own home.

column2: Thank God, we leave this vile place tomorrow.
column3: Thank God, we leave this vile place tomorrow.

column2: Since you went away, I have had no pleasure in it--the dust is beyond anything; and everybody one cares for is gone.
column3: Since you went away, I have had no pleasure in it-the dust is beyond anything; and everybody one cares for is gone.

column2: I believe if I could see you I should not mind the rest, for you are dearer to me than anybody can conceive.
column3: I believe if I could see you I should not mind the rest, for you are dearer to me than anybody can conceive.

column2: I am quite uneasy about your dear brother, not having heard from him since he went to Oxford; and am fearful of some misunderstanding.
column3: I am quite uneasy about your dear brother, not having heard from him since he went to Oxford; and am fearful of some misunderstanding.

column2: Your kind offices will set all right: he is the only man I ever did or could love, and I trust you will convince him of it. The spring fashions are partly down; and the hats the most frightful you can imagine.
column3: Your kind offices will set all right: he is the only man I ever did or could love, and I trust you will convince him of it. The spring fashions are partly down; and the hats the most frightful you can imagine.

column2: I hope you spend your time pleasantly, but am afraid you never think of me.
column3: I hope you spend your time pleasantly, but am afraid you never think of me.

column2: I will not say all that I could of the family you are with, because I would not be ungenerous, or set you against those you esteem; but it is very difficult to know whom to trust, and young men never know their minds two days together.
column3: I will not say all that I could of the family you are with, because I would not be ungenerous, or set you against those you esteem; but it is very difficult to know whom to trust, and young men never know their minds two days together.

column2: I rejoice to say that the young man whom, of all others, I particularly abhor, has left Bath.
column3: I rejoice to say that the young man whom, of all others, I particularly abhor, has left Bath.

column2: You will know, from this description, I must mean Captain Tilney, who, as you may remember, was amazingly disposed to follow and tease me, before you went away.
column3: You will know, from this description, I must mean Captain Tilney, who, as you may remember, was amazingly disposed to follow and tease me, before you went away.

column2: Afterwards he got worse, and became quite my shadow.
column3: Afterwards he got worse, and became quite my shadow.

column2: Many girls might have been taken in, for never were such attentions; but I knew the fickle sex too well.
column3: Many girls might have been taken in, for never were such attentions; but I knew the fickle sex too well.

column2: He went away to his regiment two days ago, and I trust I shall never be plagued with him again.
column3: He went away to his regiment two days ago, and I trust I shall never be plagued with him again.

column2: He is the greatest coxcomb I ever saw, and amazingly disagreeable.
column3: He is the greatest coxcomb I ever saw, and amazingly disagreeable.

column2: The last two days he was always by the side of Charlotte Davis: I pitied his taste, but took no notice of him.
column3: The last two days he was always by the side of Charlotte Davis: I pitied his taste, but took no notice of him.

column2: The last time we met was in Bath Street, and I turned directly into a shop that he might not speak to me; I would not even look at him.
column3: The last time we met was in Bath Street, and I turned directly into a shop that he might not speak to me; I would not even look at him.

column2: He went into the pump-room afterwards; but I would not have followed him for all the world.
column3: He went into the pump room afterwards; but I would not have followed him for all the world.

column2: Such a contrast between him and your brother!
column3: Such a contrast between him and your brother!

column2: Pray send me some news of the latter--I am quite unhappy about him; he seemed so uncomfortable when he went away, with a cold, or something that affected his spirits.
column3: Pray send me some news of the latter-I am quite unhappy about him; he seemed so uncomfortable when he went away, with a cold, or something that affected his spirits.

column2: I would write to him myself, but have mislaid his direction; and, as I hinted above, am afraid he took something in my conduct amiss.
column3: I would write to him myself, but have mislaid his direction; and, as I hinted above, am afraid he took something in my conduct amiss.

column2: Pray explain everything to his satisfaction; or, if he still harbours any doubt, a line from himself to me, or a call at Putney when next in town, might set all to rights. I have not been to the rooms this age, nor to the play, except going in last night with the Hodges, for a frolic, at half price: they teased me into it; and I was determined they should not say I shut myself up because Tilney was gone.
column3: Pray explain everything to his satisfaction; or, if he still harbours any doubt, a line from himself to me, or a call at Putney when next in town, might set all to rights. I have not been to the rooms this age, nor to the play, except going in last night with the Hodges, for a frolic, at half price: they teased me into it; and I was determined they should not say I shut myself up because Tilney was gone.

column2: We happened to sit by the Mitchells, and they pretended to be quite surprised to see me out.
column3: We happened to sit by the Mitchells, and they pretended to be quite surprised to see me out.

column2: I knew their spite: at one time they could not be civil to me, but now they are all friendship; but I am not such a fool as to be taken in by them.
column3: I knew their spite: at one time they could not be civil to me, but now they are all friendship; but I am not such a fool as to be taken in by them.

column2: You know I have a pretty good spirit of my own.
column3: You know I have a pretty good spirit of my own.

column2: Anne Mitchell had tried to put on a turban like mine, as I wore it the week before at the concert, but made wretched work of it--it happened to become my odd face, I believe, at least Tilney told me so at the time, and said every eye was upon me; but he is the last man whose word I would take.
column3: Anne Mitchell had tried to put on a turban like mine, as I wore it the week before at the concert, but made wretched work of it-it happened to become my odd face, I believe, at least Tilney told me so at the time, and said every eye was upon me; but he is the last man whose word I would take.

column2: I wear nothing but purple now: I know I look hideous in it, but no matter--it is your dear brother's favourite colour.
column3: I wear nothing but purple now: I know I look hideous in it, but no matter-it is your dear brother's favourite colour.

column2: Lose no time, my dearest, sweetest Catherine, in writing to him and to me, Who ever am, etc.
column3: Lose no time, my dearest, sweetest Catherine, in writing to him and to me, Who ever am, etc

column2: Such a strain of shallow artifice could not impose even upon Catherine. Its inconsistencies, contradictions, and falsehood struck her from the very first.
column3: Such a strain of shallow artifice could not impose even upon Catherine. Its inconsistencies, contradictions, and falsehood struck her from the very first.

column2: She was ashamed of Isabella, and ashamed of having ever loved her.
column3: She was ashamed of Isabella, and ashamed of having ever loved her.

column2: Her professions of attachment were now as disgusting as her excuses were empty, and her demands impudent.
column3: Her professions of attachment were now as disgusting as her excuses were empty, and her demands impudent.

column2: Write to James on her behalf!	Write to james on her behalf!
column3: true

column2: No, James should never hear Isabella's name mentioned by her again."
column3: No, james should never hear Isabella's name mentioned by her again."

column2: On Henry's arrival from Woodston, she made known to him and Eleanor their brother's safety, congratulating them with sincerity on it, and reading aloud the most material passages of her letter with strong indignation.
column3: On Henry's arrival from Woodston, she made known to him and Eleanor their brother's safety, congratulating them with sincerity on it, and reading aloud the most material passages of her letter with strong indignation.

column2: When she had finished it--"So much for Isabella," she cried, "and for all our intimacy!
column3: When she had finished it-"So much for Isabella," she cried, "and for all our intimacy!

column2: She must think me an idiot, or she could not have written so; but perhaps this has served to make her character better known to me than mine is to her.
column3: She must think me an idiot, or she could not have written so; but perhaps this has served to make her character better known to me than mine is to her.

column2: I see what she has been about.
column3: I see what she has been about.

column2: She is a vain coquette, and her tricks have not answered.
column3: She is a vain coquette, and her tricks have not answered.

column2: I do not believe she had ever any regard either for James or for me, and I wish I had never known her."
column3: I do not believe she had ever any regard either for james or for me, and I wish I had never known her."

column2: It will soon be as if you never had, said Henry.
column3: It will soon be as if you never had, said Henry.

column2: There is but one thing that I cannot understand.	There is but one thing that I cannot understand.
column3: true

column2: I see that she has had designs on Captain Tilney, which have not succeeded; but I do not understand what Captain Tilney has been about all this time.
column3: I see that she has had designs on Captain Tilney, which have not succeeded; but I do not understand what Captain Tilney has been about all this time.

column2: Why should he pay her such attentions as to make her quarrel with my brother, and then fly off himself?"
column3: Why should he pay her such attentions as to make her quarrel with my brother, and then fly off himself?"

column2: I have very little to say for Frederick's motives, such as I believe them to have been.	I have very little to say for Frederick's motives, such as I believe them to have been.
column3: true

column2: He has his vanities as well as Miss Thorpe, and the chief difference is, that, having a stronger head, they have not yet injured himself.
column3: He has his vanities as well as Miss Thorpe, and the chief difference is, that, having a stronger head, they have not yet injured himself.

column2: If the effect of his behaviour does not justify him with you, we had better not seek after the cause."
column3: If the effect of his behaviour does not justify him with you, we had better not seek after the cause."

column2: Then you do not suppose he ever really cared about her?
column3: Then you do not suppose he ever really cared about her?

column2: I am persuaded that he never did.
column3: I am persuaded that he never did.

column2: And only made believe to do so for mischief's sake?
column3: And only made believe to do so for mischief's sake?

column2: Henry bowed his assent.
column3: Henry bowed his assent.

column2: Well, then, I must say that I do not like him at all.	Well, then, I must say that I do not like him at all.
column3: true

column2: Though it has turned out so well for us, I do not like him at all.
column3: Though it has turned out so well for us, I do not like him at all.

column2: As it happens, there is no great harm done, because I do not think Isabella has any heart to lose.
column3: As it happens, there is no great harm done, because I do not think Isabella has any heart to lose.

column2: But, suppose he had made her very much in love with him?"
column3: But, suppose he had made her very much in love with him?"

column2: But we must first suppose Isabella to have had a heart to lose--consequently to have been a very different creature; and, in that case, she would have met with very different treatment.
column3: But we must first suppose Isabella to have had a heart to lose-consequently to have been a very different creature; and, in that case, she would have met with very different treatment.

column2: It is very right that you should stand by your brother.
column3: It is very right that you should stand by your brother.

column2: And if you would stand by yours, you would not be much distressed by the disappointment of Miss Thorpe.	And if you would stand by yours, you would not be much distressed by the disappointment of Miss Thorpe.
column3: false

column2: But your mind is warped by an innate principle of general integrity, and therefore not accessible to the cool reasonings of family partiality, or a desire of revenge."
column3: But your mind is warped by an innate principle of general integrity, and therefore not accessible to the cool reasonings of family partiality, or a desire of revenge."

column2: Catherine was complimented out of further bitterness.
column3: Catherine was complimented out of further bitterness.

column2: Frederick could not be unpardonably guilty, while Henry made himself so agreeable.
column3: Frederick could not be unpardonably guilty, while Henry made himself so agreeable.

column2: She resolved on not answering Isabella's letter, and tried to think no more of it.
column3: She resolved on not answering Isabella's letter, and tried to think no more of it.

column2: CHAPTER 28
column3: CHAPTER twenty eight

column2: Soon after this, the general found himself obliged to go to London for a week; and he left Northanger earnestly regretting that any necessity should rob him even for an hour of Miss Morland's company, and anxiously recommending the study of her comfort and amusement to his children as their chief object in his absence.
column3: Soon after this, the general found himself obliged to go to London for a week; and he left Northanger earnestly regretting that any necessity should rob him even for an hour of Miss Morland's company, and anxiously recommending the study of her comfort and amusement to his children as their chief object in his absence.

column2: His departure gave Catherine the first experimental conviction that a loss may be sometimes a gain.
column3: His departure gave Catherine the first experimental conviction that a loss may be sometimes a gain.

column2: The happiness with which their time now passed, every employment voluntary, every laugh indulged, every meal a scene of ease and good humour, walking where they liked and when they liked, their hours, pleasures, and fatigues at their own command, made her thoroughly sensible of the restraint which the general's presence had imposed, and most thankfully feel their present release from it.
column3: The happiness with which their time now passed, every employment voluntary, every laugh indulged, every meal a scene of ease and good humour, walking where they liked and when they liked, their hours, pleasures, and fatigues at their own command, made her thoroughly sensible of the restraint which the general's presence had imposed, and most thankfully feel their present release from it.

column2: Such ease and such delights made her love the place and the people more and more every day; and had it not been for a dread of its soon becoming expedient to leave the one, and an apprehension of not being equally beloved by the other, she would at each moment of each day have been perfectly happy; but she was now in the fourth week of her visit; before the general came home, the fourth week would be turned, and perhaps it might seem an intrusion if she stayed much longer.
column3: Such ease and such delights made her love the place and the people more and more every day; and had it not been for a dread of its soon becoming expedient to leave the one, and an apprehension of not being equally beloved by the other, she would at each moment of each day have been perfectly happy; but she was now in the fourth week of her visit; before the general came home, the fourth week would be turned, and perhaps it might seem an intrusion if she stayed much longer.

column2: This was a painful consideration whenever it occurred; and eager to get rid of such a weight on her mind, she very soon resolved to speak to Eleanor about it at once, propose going away, and be guided in her conduct by the manner in which her proposal might be taken.
column3: This was a painful consideration whenever it occurred; and eager to get rid of such a weight on her mind, she very soon resolved to speak to Eleanor about it at once, propose going away, and be guided in her conduct by the manner in which her proposal might be taken.
